attributes.comment:
I am writing in opposition to this proposal to raise the I-600/I-600a fees by an
exorbitant amount without compensating adoptive families in other respects. As
the adoption process gets longer for many countries, many waiting families are
required to re-submit this form and pay the fee again (possibly up to 3x). This is a
legal form of extortion. The first fee is paid so that a family's homestudy remains
valid for a year, and then if the family wants to keep it valid, they must pay again.

I would recommend that if this fee is to be increased, then the validity of the form
should remain in effect for a greater period of time. Similarly, if the adoption tax
credit were to be increased by $500-$1000 to offset this cost, this would be an
amenable solution.

It doesn't bode well when anyone in this country can birth a child relatively
inexpensively (to the family). Additionally, many of these children are born out of
wedlock and to low-income families (or single mothers) who lack motivation or
incentive to be productive citizens in this country. This cycle is self-perpetuating
in many cases, so the pattern repeats itself for many generations. Adoptive
families make the conscious choice to build a family. They are highly productive
citizens of this country who are resourceful enough to raise a child who will be
equally productive. Why punish these individuals without an equal compensation
for their sacrifice?
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Troy Brock
